Congratulations again to our AP students!

She is a true leader who “heads” a cohesive team where there is equity in duties and planning. Dawn rarely seems overwhelmed and always seems calm and collected. She systematically and thoughtfully problem solves difficult situations. She is solution-oriented and models masterful teaching. Her room is a sea of calm, even though things could change on a dime. Ms. Dorman always keeps students engaged and interested and knows when to push, when to back off, and when to cheerlead. She is GEM…a natural…a master teacher! Thanks for all that you do, Ms. Dorman! #CapeProud

post_text: Congratulations to this morning's GEM nominee recipient, Mrs. Deborah Gaudlip, an instructional paraprofessional at Milton Elementary. We are so fortunate to have Mrs. Gaudlip at MES. She is a true asset school-wide. While Mrs. Gaudlip provides instructional and behavioral support for students in grades 2-5, she also is supporting any school needs. Currently, she is reaching out to the Cape community by working at the Friday food distributions. Her familiar face that is always smiling helps to bridge and build many relationships between faculty and families. In these difficult times, Mrs. Gaudlip has been invaluable in providing other outreach services. She has assisted in reaching out to families to identify families needing technology support. We are so proud to have Mrs. Gaudlip as part of our team! #CapeProud

Juneteenth is a holiday celebrated on June 19th to commemorate the emancipation of enslaved people in the US. The holiday was first celebrated in Texas, where on that date in 1865, in the aftermath of the Civil War, slaves were declared free under the terms of the 1862 Emancipation Proclamation.

There will be NO Grab and Go Meal Delivery tomorrow due to the District being closed. We've updated the text in our previous post, and updated flyers reflecting that change are below!

Thank you for your continued support, understanding, and patience with us as we navigate through these challenges.

Sincerely,
Bob Fulton
Superintendent

post_text: Good morning and happy Monday! Today we'd like to recognize Ms. Maria Gaito as the Rehoboth Elementary GEM nominee for the month of February! Ms. Gaito’s compassionate and nurturing spirit has touched the lives of hundreds of students for the past 29 years. The bonds that she and her kindergarten students form stretch beyond the students’ first year of learning. This is evident as students return to her classroom for a morning greeting or an afternoon hug long after they have advanced to other grades. In fact, students who are not in her class or siblings of her students also stop and greet her. She is truly a devoted educator who seeks to understand the whole child and does not hesitate to seek assistance to meet a child’s every need. Her proactive efforts to connect daily with parents are genuine and reflective. She also serves as the coordinator of kindergarten registration and as the Positive Behavior Support Kindergarten Representative. Thank you for all that you do for the students and families in our District, Ms. Gaito! #CapeProud

Today we are Rocking our Socks for World Down Syndrome Day!

A day to celebrate and create a single global voice for advocating for the rights, inclusion and well being of people with Down syndrome in our schools, community and around the world. 3/21 was selected to signify the uniqueness of the triplication (trisomy) of the 21st chromosome which leads to Down syndrome.

The first GEM nominee we'd like to recognize today is Mr. Tim Eitner, a custodian at H.O. Brittingham!

Recently Mr. Eitner was called into action by our school nurse when a student had their finger stuck in a hard plastic tube. Cold water and soap were not working to free the student's finger, and the nurse even had tried to use her metal cutting scissors to cut the tube but was unsuccessful. As soon as Mr. Eitner was called to assist with the situation, he jumped into action and got his heavy-duty wire cutters! Mr. Eitner gently began to clip away pieces of the tube until it opened enough for the student to free their finger unharmed! Mr. Eitner sure is a GEM!
We are thankful for the many ways that Mr. Eitner helps the staff and students at HOB on a daily basis! #CapeProud

The Cape Henlopen High School GEM nominee for November is Physical Education teacher, Ms. Candy Brown! Ms. Miller and Mr. Bentley received the following note from a parent:
“On Friday morning, my daughter called me from school to tell me that she had a flat tire. Totally flat! My husband has been down for the count with a back issue, so I was wondering how I would get this all figured out before the end of her school day. I owe Mrs. Brown a huge thank you. When my daughter saw her that morning and told her what was happening, she immediately took action. Not only did she change her tire to the spare for her, but she taught her where things were and how to change the tire. One more example of Cape teachers going above and beyond the teacher expectations! I am so happy to be part of the Cape Family!” Thank you for all that you do for our students Ms. Brown! #CapeProud

post_text: Congratulations to Mrs. Christine Donofrio who is the GEM nominee from Milton Elementary School! Mrs. Donofrio is a Child Nutrition Services member who goes above and beyond on a daily basis. Mrs. Donofrio is able to do all the jobs in the cafeteria, but most often can be found behind the cash register. She greets each student by name and with a smile. When a child forgets his or her student identification number, she is always patient and encouraging. She spreads kindness daily. For example, as Dr. Conaway was giving two new students and their families a tour of the building, I showed them the cafeteria. Mrs. Donofrio greeted them, asked them their names, and then said she would like to buy them ice cream to welcome them to Milton Elementary School. The girls were so excited, and the mothers couldn’t believe the offer. Mrs. Donofrio ensures that the cafeteria is welcoming to all students. She decorates the cafeteria monthly so that it is an engaging space. She is a very special person to everyone at MES! #CapeProud

U.S. Senator Chris Coons is at Air Mobility Command Museum.
December 17, 2019 at 10:22 PM · Dover Air Force Base, DE ·

I’m thrilled to announce my principal nominees for appointment to our service academies for the Class of 2024!

Amanda Carey, a student at Dover High School and volunteer with the Dover Fire Dept., is my principal nominee to the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Maryland.

Andrew Garza, a student at POLYTECH High School and volunteer with Habitat for Humanity, is one of my principal nominees to the U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado.

Mackenzie Irelan, a student at Cape Henlopen High School and member of the softball team, is my principal nominee for West Point - The U.S. Military Academy in New York.

Donald Mendoza, a student at Caesar Rodney High School and an eagle scout with the Boy Scouts of America, is my other principal nominee for the U.S. Air Force Academy.

These young men and women – all from Kent and Sussex Counties – have already accomplished so much, and it speaks volumes that they are now committing to serve our country in uniform. I’m so proud of each one of them, and I can’t wait to see all the amazing things they do in future.

post_text: Mrs. Dawn Ramirez is the GEM nominee representing the Sussex Consortium! Mrs. Ramirez is a teacher in our Life Skills Development Center program. Mrs. Ramirez recently volunteered to take on an extra caseload after losing her co-teacher to another opportunity in the District. In addition to now managing two caseloads, Mrs. Ramirez serves as respite coordinator for all of our SC families throughout Sussex County, delivers homebound instruction to our SC students that medically require such a setting and is a mentor for novice teachers in our program. She represents her peers by serving as a SIT representative and as a member of the SC secondary trauma team, while still finding time to assist her peers with technology issues related to Schoology. We are so grateful for all that she does for our students, families and staff! #CapeProud

She has worked collaboratively with teachers to create an intervention schedule that meets the student’s IEP needs as well as ensure the students are not missing key classroom instruction. Mrs. Reynolds shares strategies and resources with parents and teachers. During IEP meetings, she explains the progress students have made and creates meaningful goals. Besides working on speech goals, Mrs. Reynolds supports the students' social and emotional needs as well. She works with students in small groups and ensures that they learn to take turns, listen to one another, and support one another as they work to master their goals. Congratulations Mrs. Reynolds and thank you for all that you do! #CapeProud

Delaware Department of Education (DDOE)
November 8, 2019 at 11:21 AM ·

David McDowell of Cape Henlopen School District, Jean Briggs of Seaford School District, and Walter Smith of Indian River School District - Delaware, had the opportunity to meet with Senator Tom Carper during the recent National Association for the Education of Homeless Children and Youth Conference, held in Washington, DC.

These three Delaware educators, who are homeless education liaisons for their school districts, were among more than 30 representatives from Delaware. They attended key notes and breakout sessions to gain additional information on educating students who are experiencing homelessness.

Each school district and charter school has a homeless education liaison who assists families who are displaced. Please see https://www.doe.k12.de.us/domain/362 for more information.
